# 1. Getting Started

## 1.1 Import Packages

-   [`sf`](https://r-spatial.github.io/sf/) for handling geospatial data.

-   [`tidyverse`](https://www.tidyverse.org/) for manipulating and wrangling data.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pacman::p_load(sf, tidyverse)
```
:::


## 1.2 Import Data

Importing `shape-file` of Master Plan 2024 Sub-zone Boundary.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz_shp <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/MasterPlan2014SubzoneBoundaryWebSHP", layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields

Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
```


:::
:::


Importing `KML` file.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# mpsz_kml = st_read("data/geospatial/MasterPlan2014SubzoneBoundaryWebKML.kml")
```
:::


::: callout-warning
The above code cannot run, as the KML file was corrupted.
:::

## 1.3. Export Data Frame into KML file

The code chunk below export the data frame into KML file.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_write(mpsz_shp,
         "data/geospatial/mpsz.kml",
         delete_dsn = TRUE)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Deleting source `data/geospatial/mpsz.kml' using driver `KML'
Writing layer `mpsz' to data source `data/geospatial/mpsz.kml' using driver `KML'
Writing 323 features with 15 fields and geometry type Multi Polygon.
```


:::
:::


::: callout-note
`delete_dsn` is is used to specify whether the existing data source (the file you're writing to) should be deleted before writing new data into it. Useful when we want to overwrite the existing file.
:::

# 2. Importing MPSZ 2019

Import Shape-file


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz2019_shp <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/MPSZNoSeaSHP", layer = "MPSZ-2019")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `MPSZ-2019' from data source 
  `/Users/mingwei/Desktop/SMU/Y3S1/IS415/xXxPMWxXx/IS415-GAA/In-class_Ex/In-class_Ex02/data/geospatial/MPSZNoSeaSHP' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 332 features and 6 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
```


:::
:::


Import KML file


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz2019_kml = st_read("data/geospatial/MasterPlan2019SubzoneBoundaryNoSeaKML.kml")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `URA_MP19_SUBZONE_NO_SEA_PL' from data source 
  `/Users/mingwei/Desktop/SMU/Y3S1/IS415/xXxPMWxXx/IS415-GAA/In-class_Ex/In-class_Ex02/data/geospatial/MasterPlan2019SubzoneBoundaryNoSeaKML.kml' 
  using driver `LIBKML'
Simple feature collection with 332 features and 22 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
```


:::
:::


::: callout-tip
If in the `geometry` col raw data, if the data was small such as 103, then most likely the data set will be in Geographical Coordinate Systems(GCS) (e.g. WGS84), which means we need do additional step to convert the data set to Projected Coordinate Systems (PCS) (e.g. SVY21, CRS = 3414)

Note: if the data set is in PCS, then the `geometry` col data will be much larger.
:::

## 2.1 Transforming coordinate system


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz2019_shp <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/MPSZNoSeaSHP", 
                        layer = "MPSZ-2019") %>%
                st_transform(crs = 3414)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `MPSZ-2019' from data source 
  `/Users/mingwei/Desktop/SMU/Y3S1/IS415/xXxPMWxXx/IS415-GAA/In-class_Ex/In-class_Ex02/data/geospatial/MPSZNoSeaSHP' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 332 features and 6 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
```


:::
:::


## 2.2 Checking coordinate system

To check what CRS the data frame is using


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_crs(mpsz2019_shp)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Coordinate Reference System:
  User input: EPSG:3414 
  wkt:
PROJCRS["SVY21 / Singapore TM",
    BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21",
        DATUM["SVY21",
            ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,
                LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]]],
        PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]],
        ID["EPSG",4757]],
    CONVERSION["Singapore Transverse Mercator",
        METHOD["Transverse Mercator",
            ID["EPSG",9807]],
        PARAMETER["Latitude of natural origin",1.36666666666667,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8801]],
        PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8802]],
        PARAMETER["Scale factor at natural origin",1,
            SCALEUNIT["unity",1],
            ID["EPSG",8805]],
        PARAMETER["False easting",28001.642,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8806]],
        PARAMETER["False northing",38744.572,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8807]]],
    CS[Cartesian,2],
        AXIS["northing (N)",north,
            ORDER[1],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
        AXIS["easting (E)",east,
            ORDER[2],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
    USAGE[
        SCOPE["Cadastre, engineering survey, topographic mapping."],
        AREA["Singapore - onshore and offshore."],
        BBOX[1.13,103.59,1.47,104.07]],
    ID["EPSG",3414]]
```


:::
:::


# 3. Working with Population Data


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
popdata <- st_read("data/aspatial/respopagesextod2023.csv")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `respopagesextod2023' from data source 
  `/Users/mingwei/Desktop/SMU/Y3S1/IS415/xXxPMWxXx/IS415-GAA/In-class_Ex/In-class_Ex02/data/aspatial/respopagesextod2023.csv' 
  using driver `CSV'
```


:::
:::


## 3.1 Data Wrangling


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
popdata2023 <- popdata %>%
  group_by(PA, SZ, AG) %>%
  summarise(`POP` = sum(as.numeric(`Pop`))) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  pivot_wider(names_from=AG, 
              values_from=POP)
```
:::


To check the col order


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
colnames(popdata2023)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 [1] "PA"          "SZ"          "0_to_4"      "10_to_14"    "15_to_19"   
 [6] "20_to_24"    "25_to_29"    "30_to_34"    "35_to_39"    "40_to_44"   
[11] "45_to_49"    "50_to_54"    "55_to_59"    "5_to_9"      "60_to_64"   
[16] "65_to_69"    "70_to_74"    "75_to_79"    "80_to_84"    "85_to_89"   
[21] "90_and_Over"
```


:::
:::


## 3.2 Data Processing


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
popdata2023 <- popdata2023 %>%
  mutate(YOUNG = rowSums(.[3:6])
         +rowSums(.[14])) %>%
mutate(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` = rowSums(.[7:13])+
rowSums(.[15]))%>%
mutate(`AGED`=rowSums(.[16:21])) %>%
mutate(`TOTAL`=rowSums(.[3:21])) %>%  
mutate(`DEPENDENCY` = (`YOUNG` + `AGED`)
/`ECONOMY ACTIVE`) %>%
  select(`PA`, `SZ`, `YOUNG`, 
       `ECONOMY ACTIVE`, `AGED`, 
       `TOTAL`, `DEPENDENCY`)
```
:::


## 3.3 Joining popdata2023 and mpsz19_shp


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
popdata2023 <- popdata2023 %>% mutate_at(.vars = vars(PA,SZ), .funs = list(toupper))
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz_pop2023 <- left_join(mpsz2019_shp, popdata2023, by = c("SUBZONE_N" = "SZ"))
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pop2023_mpsz <- left_join(popdata2023, mpsz2019_shp,
                          by = c("SZ" = "SUBZONE_N"))
```
:::
